title: R Package Template
text: open source R package MAIC

what: Bucher method for adjusted treatment effect — bucher
title: Bucher method for adjusted treatment effect — bucher
text: Given two estimated treatment effects vs. C B vs. C (.e. two point estimates corresponding standard errors), derive adjusted treatment vs. B using Bucher method, two-sided confidence limits Z-test p-value

title: Bucher method for adjusted treatment effect — bucher
code: bucher(trt, com, conf_lv = 0.95)

title: Bucher method for adjusted treatment effect — bucher
text: trt list two named scalars study interested experimental arm, one named 'est' point estimate, named 'se' standard error com trt, study interested control arm conf_lv numerical scalar, prescribe confidence level derive two-sided confidence interval adjusted treatment effect

title: Bucher method for adjusted treatment effect — bucher
text: list 5 elements, est scalar, point estimate adjusted treatment effect se scalar, standard error adjusted treatment effect (.e. est return) ci_l scalar, lower confidence limit two-sided CI prescribed nominal level conf_lv ci_u scalar, upper confidence limit two-sided CI prescribed nominal level conf_lv pval p-value Z-test, null hypothesis est zero

what: Center individual patient data (IPD) variables using aggregate data averages — center_ipd
title: Center individual patient data (IPD) variables using aggregate data averages — center_ipd
text: function subtracts IPD variables (prognostic variables /effect modifiers) aggregate data averages. centering needed order calculate weights. IPD aggregate data variable names match.

title: Center individual patient data (IPD) variables using aggregate data averages — center_ipd
code: center_ipd(ipd, agd)

title: Center individual patient data (IPD) variables using aggregate data averages — center_ipd
text: ipd IPD variable names match aggregate data names without suffix. involve either changing aggregate data name ipd name. instance, binarize SEX variable MALE reference, function names new variable SEX_MALE. case, SEX_MALE also available aggregate data. agd pre-processed aggregate data contain STUDY, ARM, N. Variable names followed legal suffixes (.e. MEAN, MEDIAN, SD, PROP). Note COUNT suffix longer accepted.

title: Center individual patient data (IPD) variables using aggregate data averages — center_ipd
text: centered ipd using aggregate level data averages

title: Check to see if weights are optimized correctly — check_weights
text: optimized object returned calculating weights using estimate_weights processed_agd data frame, object returned using process_agd aggregated data following naming convention mean_digits number digits rounding mean columns output prop_digits number digits rounding proportion columns output sd_digits number digits rounding mean columns output

title: Check to see if weights are optimized correctly — check_weights
text: data.frame weighted unweighted covariate averages IPD

title: Calculate pooled arm statistics in Aggregated Data (AgD) based on arm-specific statistics — complete_agd

what: Create dummy variables from categorical variables in an individual patient data (ipd) — dummize_ipd
title: Create dummy variables from categorical variables in an individual patient data (ipd) — dummize_ipd
text: convenient function convert categorical variables dummy binary variables. especially useful variable two factors. Note original variable kept variable dummized.

title: Create dummy variables from categorical variables in an individual patient data (ipd) — dummize_ipd
code: dummize_ipd(raw_ipd, dummize_cols, dummize_ref_level)

title: Create dummy variables from categorical variables in an individual patient data (ipd) — dummize_ipd
text: raw_ipd ipd data contains variable dummize dummize_cols vector column names binarize dummize_ref_level vector reference level variables binarize

title: Create dummy variables from categorical variables in an individual patient data (ipd) — dummize_ipd

what: Derive individual weights in the matching step of MAIC — estimate_weights
title: Derive individual weights in the matching step of MAIC — estimate_weights
text: Assuming data properly processed, function takes individual patient data (IPD) centered covariates (effect modifiers /prognostic variables) input, generates weights individual IPD trial matches chosen statistics covariates Aggregated Data (AgD) trial.

title: Derive individual weights in the matching step of MAIC — estimate_weights
code: estimate_weights(   data,   centered_colnames = NULL,   start_val = 0,   method = "BFGS",   ... )

title: Derive individual weights in the matching step of MAIC — estimate_weights
text: data numeric matrix, centered covariates IPD, missing value cell allowed centered_colnames character numeric vector (column indicators) centered covariates start_val scalar, starting value coefficients propensity score regression method string, name optimization algorithm (see 'method' argument base::optim()). default "BFGS", options "Nelder-Mead", "CG", "L-BFGS-B", "SANN", "Brent" ... arguments base::optim()

title: Derive individual weights in the matching step of MAIC — estimate_weights
text: list following 4 elements, data data.frame, includes input data appended column 'weights' 'scaled_weights'. Scaled weights summation number rows data missing value effect modifiers centered_colnames column names centered effect modifiers data nr_missing number rows data least 1 missing value specified centered effect modifiers ess effective sample size, square sum divided sum squares opt R object returned base::optim(), assess convergence details

what: helper function: transform TTE ADaM data to suitable input for survival R pkg — ext_tte_transfer
title: helper function: transform TTE ADaM data to suitable input for survival R pkg — ext_tte_transfer

title: helper function: transform TTE ADaM data to suitable input for survival R pkg — ext_tte_transfer
code: ext_tte_transfer(dd, time_scale = "month", trt = NULL)

title: helper function: transform TTE ADaM data to suitable input for survival R pkg — ext_tte_transfer
text: dd data frame, ADTTE read via haven::read_sas time_scale character string, 'year', 'month', 'week' 'day', time unit median survival time trt values include treatment column

title: helper function: transform TTE ADaM data to suitable input for survival R pkg — ext_tte_transfer
text: data frame can used input survival::Surv

title: Generate time-to-event data — generate_survival_data
text: Function generates time--event data. follow data-generating mechanism Bender et al. Remiro-Azocar et al. 2021 simulate Weibull-distributed survival times proportional hazards parameterization. per Remiro-Azocar et al, set default scale parameter (lambda) 8.5 shape parameter (nu) 1.3 reflect frequently observed mortality trends metastatic cancer patients. Censoring times generated exponential distribution rate parameter 0.96 selected achieve censoring rate 35% active treatment baseline (values covariates set zero).

title: Generate time-to-event data — generate_survival_data
code: generate_survival_data(   N = 150,   ncov = 4,   lambda = 8.5,   nu = 1.3,   censor_rate = 0.96,   cor = 0.35,   marginal_mean = 0.6,   marginal_sd = 0.2,   beta = rep(-log(0.67), ncov),   gamma = sort(rep(c(0, -log(0.67)), length = ncov)),   d0 = log(0.25),   seed = 1 )

title: Generate time-to-event data — generate_survival_data
text: N sample size ncov number covariates generate lambda scale parameter baseline hazard function nu shape parameter baseline hazard function censor_rate rate parameter exponential distribution censoring times cor correlation covariates marginal_mean marginal mean covariates marginal_sd marginal standard deviation covariates beta vector coefficients prognostic factors. Defaults -log(0.67) covariates. gamma vector coefficients effect modifiers. Default 0 half covariates -log(0.67) others. d0 coefficient treatment effect patients treat = 0 seed seed used simulation reproducibility

title: Generate time-to-event data — generate_survival_data
text: data.frame survival time, censor (event) status, treatment indicator, covariates

title: Generate time-to-event data — generate_survival_data
text: Remiro-Azocar et al. 2021

what: Unanchored MAIC for time-to-event endpoint — maic_tte_unanchor
title: Unanchored MAIC for time-to-event endpoint — maic_tte_unanchor
text: Unanchored MAIC time--event endpoint

title: Unanchored MAIC for time-to-event endpoint — maic_tte_unanchor
code: maic_tte_unanchor(   useWt,   dat,   dat_ext,   trt,   trt_ext,   time_scale = "month",   endpoint_name = "OS",   transform = "log" )

title: Unanchored MAIC for time-to-event endpoint — maic_tte_unanchor
text: useWt numeric vector individual MAIC weights, length nrow(dat) dat data frame meet format requirements 'Details', individual patient data (IPD) internal trial dat_ext data frame, pseudo IPD digitized KM curve external trial trt character string, name interested treatment internal trial (real IPD) trt_ext character string, name interested comparator external trial used subset dat_ext (pseudo IPD) time_scale character string, 'year', 'month', 'week' 'day', time unit median survival time endpoint_name character string, name endpoint transform character string, pass cox.zph

title: Unanchored MAIC for time-to-event endpoint — maic_tte_unanchor
text: Format requirements input dat dat_ext following columns treatment - character factor column status - logical column, TRUE censored/death, FALSE otherwise time - numeric column, observation time status; unit days

what: Plot MAIC weights in a histogram with key statistics in legend — plot_weights
title: Plot MAIC weights in a histogram with key statistics in legend — plot_weights
text: Generates plot given individuals weights key summary top right legend includes median weight, effective sample size (ESS), reduction percentage (percent ESS reduced original sample size). two options weights provided estimate_weights: unscaled scaled. Scaled weights relative original unit weights individual. words, scaled weight greater 1 means individual carries weight re-weighted population original data scaled weight less 1 means individual carries less weight re-weighted population original data.

title: Plot MAIC weights in a histogram with key statistics in legend — plot_weights
code: plot_weights(   wt,   bin_col = "#6ECEB2",   vline_col = "#688CE8",   main_title = "Unscaled Individual Weights" )

title: Plot MAIC weights in a histogram with key statistics in legend — plot_weights
text: wt numeric vector individual MAIC weights (derived using estimate_weights) bin_col string, color bins histogram vline_col string, color vertical line histogram main_title character string, main title plot

title: Plot MAIC weights in a histogram with key statistics in legend — plot_weights
text: plot unscaled scaled weights

what: Report-friendly output format for result from Bucher's method — print_bucher
title: Report-friendly output format for result from Bucher's method — print_bucher
text: Report-friendly output format result Bucher's method

title: Report-friendly output format for result from Bucher's method — print_bucher
code: print_bucher(output, ci_digits = 2, pval_digits = 3)

title: Report-friendly output format for result from Bucher's method — print_bucher
text: output output bucher function ci_digits integer, number decimal places point estimate derived confidence limits pval_digits integer, number decimal places display Z-test p-value

title: Report-friendly output format for result from Bucher's method — print_bucher
text: character vector two elements, first element format 'est (ci_l; ci_u)'`, second element Z-test p-value, rounded according pval_digits

title: Pre-process aggregate data — process_agd
text: function checks format aggregate data. Data required three columns: STUDY, ARM, N. Column names legal suffixes (MEAN, MEDIAN, SD, COUNT, PROP) dropped. variable count variable, converted proportions dividing sample size (N). Note, count specified, proportion always calculated based count, , specified proportion ignored applicable. aggregated data comes multiple sources (.e. different analysis population) sample size differs variable, one option specify proportion directly instead count using suffix _PROP.

title: Pre-process aggregate data — process_agd
code: process_agd(raw_agd)

title: Pre-process aggregate data — process_agd
text: raw_agd raw aggregate data contain STUDY, ARM, N. Variable names followed legal suffixes (.e. MEAN, MEDIAN, SD, COUNT, PROP).

title: Pre-process aggregate data — process_agd
text: pre-processed aggregate level data

title: Pre-process aggregate data — process_agd
code: # example target_pop <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "aggregate_data_example_1.csv",   package = "maicplus", mustWork = TRUE )) #> Warning: incomplete final line found by readTableHeader on '/usr/local/lib/R/site-library/maicplus/extdata/aggregate_data_example_1.csv' target_pop2 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "aggregate_data_example_2.csv",   package = "maicplus", mustWork = TRUE )) #> Warning: incomplete final line found by readTableHeader on '/usr/local/lib/R/site-library/maicplus/extdata/aggregate_data_example_2.csv' target_pop3 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "aggregate_data_example_3.csv",   package = "maicplus", mustWork = TRUE )) #> Warning: incomplete final line found by readTableHeader on '/usr/local/lib/R/site-library/maicplus/extdata/aggregate_data_example_3.csv'  target_pop <- process_agd(target_pop) target_pop2 <- process_agd(target_pop2) target_pop3 <- process_agd(target_pop3)  # another example target_pop <- data.frame(   STUDY = "Study_XXXX",   ARM = "Total",   N = 300,   AGE_MEAN = 51,   AGE_MEDIAN = 49,   AGE_SD = 3.25,   SEX_MALE_COUNT = 147,   ECOG0_COUNT = 105,   SMOKE_PROP = 58 / 290 ) process_agd(target_pop) #>        STUDY   ARM   N AGE_MEAN AGE_MEDIAN AGE_SD SEX_MALE_PROP ECOG0_PROP #> 1 Study_XXXX Total 300       51         49   3.25          0.49       0.35 #>   SMOKE_PROP #> 1        0.2
